intro: Oxytropis chrysocarpa, commonly known as the golden fruit locoweed, is a perennial herb native to the arid regions of western North America. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its spiny stems and small, compound leaves. The plant produces yellow flowers in early spring, followed by distinctive, inflated pods that contain seeds. It is adapted to harsh, dry environments and has a deep root system for water absorption. Oxytropis chrysocarpa is often found in sagebrush steppe and desert habitats.
